<denchmark-link:https://github.com/krishnadurai>@krishnadurai</denchmark-link> Where did you see the error "iap.oauth2ClientSecret" What value did you provide for the OAuth2 client secret?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/jlewi>@jlewi</denchmark-link> This was in the GCP cloud console. Navigating to Kubernetes Engine - Services and Ingress and clicking on envoy-ingress. This is where I had gotten the error. I'll just re-test and report here.

I've tested this again and it is working with a fresh run. Seems the CLIENT_SECRET could have been picked by from an earlier bash value. Should we add a check at the beginning for CLIENT_ID - CLIENT_SECRET compatibility?

kfctl generate will complain if CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET aren't defined, but I think you're saying that we should verify these values are correct - maybe through some http operation like HEAD or GET. The error message seems correct. Perhaps relabel this as an enhancement? /platform gcp /area gcp /priority p3
Agreed, we can change the label.

I don't believe there is any API we can use to validate the client and secret. The troubleshooting doc has instructions for changing the OAuth credential after it is deployed <denchmark-link:https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/gke/troubleshooting-gke/#changing-the-oauth-client-used-by-iap>https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/gke/troubleshooting-gke/#changing-the-oauth-client-used-by-iap</denchmark-link>
Then we should close this issue. Since the docs cover enough on how to tackle this problem. /close
